III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section Program statement
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Sometime between March 2024 and April 30, 2025, the unknown
child drew a sexually explicit picture of a nude female. The child
also wrote on the drawing several phrases in Spanish on the
picture including, "Sex is good", Everybody needs sex", and "Sex
is needed". The Responsive Deployment Children's Shelter CEO
(Administrator 1, last name unknown) told shelter staff to put the
drawing away in their desk and not to speak of it again because
the shelter is new and could not afford a "ding" against the shelter.
It is not known if anyone spoke to the child about this drawing.
Investigation Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/6/2025. She reported not being aware of the allegations but was
able to identify the facility owner’s (COO) name which matched
Administrator 1 who had visited the facility twice last year. She
also reported a belief that Administrator 1 would not have become
involved in something as described in the allegations because
Administrator 1 would have let the program handle such an issue.
She reported there were no youth in the program until 8/16/24 and
Administrator 1 came to the facility twice in the spring of 2024 and
spent less than a day total while onsite. Administrator 2 was
interviewed again face-to-face at the facility on 5/21/2025. She
reported the same process as Administrator 3 (described below)
in the handling of situations as described in the allegations. The
Office of Refugee and Resettlement (ORR) would be notified and
a note along with the picture would be placed in the youth’s file.
Currently, she will need to contact ORR to request the file since it
has been closed.
2

Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 5/9/2025. He
denied the allegations and reported there were no youth in the
program during the times he came to the facility. He reported
coming to the facility at the end of May 2024 or early June 2024.
He also reported the facility was not ready to receive youth until
August 2024 and there were only a few employees at the facility
when he visited. He reported a strong desire to run the facility the
“right way” and would never engage in covering something up.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 5/16/2025. Staff 2
reported it was Administrator 3 who spoke with Administrator 4
and was told the facility was past the time to report the incident
and not to report. Staff 2 also reported receiving the picture 72-
hours after the youth drew the picture over the weekend from
Supervisor 1. Staff 2 could not recall the name of the youth that
was alleged to have drawn the picture. Staff 2 reported the youth
left the program and Staff 2 asked Administrator 3 what Staff 2
should do about the picture. Staff 2 reported Administrator 5 knew
about the situation and so did Staff 1. Staff 2 reported the picture
is still in the grievance box in a folder at the facility. Staff 2
reported calling Office of Refugee and Resettlement (ORR) but
never hearing anything after reporting the allegations.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/21/2025. He denied ever telling a staff member to hide a picture
or other information because it was too late to report. He also
denied knowing about a picture of a naked female being drawn by
youth nor having Administrator 4 tell him to hide the picture. He
reported taking over as the Program Director on 1/23/2025 and
having only three youth in the program at the time. He also
reported he would report an incident regardless of the length of
time after the incident. He reported grievance boxes are checked
twice a day (once on each shift), and all grievances are placed in
a binder with a copy placed in the youth’s file and there is no
evidence that a grievance was ever filed about this picture
incident. He also reported the procedure if coming across a
picture as described in the allegations is to contact ORR and
report along with placing the picture and note in the youth’s file.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/21/2025. She reported Youth A drew a picture of a naked female
at the beginning of the year when there were several other youths
in the program. She also reported taking the picture from Youth A
and giving it to Supervisor 1. She reported Youth A was smiling
and laughing when she took the picture from Youth A. She also
reported Supervisor 1 informed her, she did the right thing by
3

taking the picture and reporting it to Supervisor 1. She was unable
to remember what other staff were informed or had knowledge of
the picture. Staff 1 was shown the picture of a naked female found
in the grievance folder but was unable to recall if this was the
picture she took from Youth A.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/21/2025. She was given the picture and reported remembering
the day Staff 1 gave her the picture. She reported Youth B drew
the picture during class and this occurred in the fall of 2024. She
reported sending the picture to Staff 2 who told her Staff 2 would
speak to Youth B about the picture and put a note in Youth B’s
file, since that was Staff 2’s primary role at the facility.
Administrator 4 was interviewed via phone on 5/21/2025.
Administrator 4 reported only hearing about the allegations after
the special investigation was initiated. She denied ever speaking
to Administrator 3 about any inappropriate pictures. She also
reported that she would never instruct something to be hidden to
avoid a violation but rather would follow up on any concerns.
Administrator 5 was interviewed via phone on 5/21/2025. She
denied having any knowledge of the allegations or being made
aware of any inappropriate pictures. She reported going through
her emails and finding nothing about this allegation being reported
to her.
Administrator 2 was interviewed for the third time face-to-
face at the facility on 6/6/2025. She reported there is no
evidence in the two youth’s (Youth A and Youth B) closed files of
a behavior incident about drawing a picture of a naked female
being placed in the file. She also reported there is further evidence
of Staff 2 not completing her job responsibilities which lead to Staff
2’s termination.
Youth A and Youth B were both placed with family and their
whereabouts at this time are unknown. Therefore, there was no
way to contact the youth. Both youths were placed out of the
state of Michigan.
Documents Reviewed:
Email from Administrator 1 dated 5/9/2025. This document
indicates Administrator 1 visited the facility on February 26-28,
2024, for 2 nights and May 29-31, 2024, for 2 nights.
4

Hand drawn picture of Naked female. Within the folder found in
the grievance box a hand drawn picture of a naked female was
found. The name on the picture did not appear to be Youth A’s
name but possibility Youth B’s name.
Responsive Deployment Policy and Acknowledgement: Code
of Conduct dated 1/14/24. This document outlines staff are to
protect youth from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and
inappropriate sexual behavior as well as other forms of physical
abuse, verbal/emotional abuse, and neglect. It is stated that staff
are to report knowledge, suspicion, or information the before
mentioned concerns.
Responsive Deployment Policy: PSA Compliance Manager
not dated. This document outlines the responsibilities of the PSA
Compliance Manager as preventing, detecting, and responding to
sexual abuse and harassment. The PSA Manager is to collaborate
will all staff, volunteers, contractors, and subcontractors who
interaction with youth at the facility to ensure they understand
policy of reporting sexual abuse or harassment.
Responsive Deployment Policy: PSA Prevention of Sexual
Abuse not dated. This document outlines the need for pre-
service training, background criminal checks, reference checks
and onboarding process. Each of these action steps are to be
monitored by the PSA Manager to ensure compliance. All staff are
also to be trained about taking action as a mandated reporter and
this also is to be monitored by the PSA Manager.
Responsive Deployment Policy: PSA Reporting Child Abuse
and Neglect not dated. This document states the PSA Manager
is to ensure staff follow the Michigan State reporting guidelines.
Responsive Deployment Policy: Child Abuse Mandated
Reporter not dated. This document outlines that all staff must
read and sign this policy. The PSA Manager is to monitor the
personal file for a copy of this document in each file. Sexual
Abuse – Behavioral Indicates are listed as, withdrawal, chronic
depression, sexual behaviors, or reference that are unusual for
the youth’s age, Seductive or promiscuous behavior, Poor self-
esteem, self-devaluation, lack of confidence, Suicide attempts,
hysteria, and lack of emotional control. Sexual harassment of a
minor by another minor includes “pictures sent or shown”.
Inappropriate sexual behavior includes offensive conduct that is
not serious enough to rise to the level of sexual abuse and has not
occurred repeatedly as to constitute sexual harassment. It is
5

stated that if a youth perpetrates an act that meets the definition of
inappropriate sexual behavior the staff must report the incident to
all appropriate entities.
Responsive Deployment Policy: Prevention of Sexual Abuse
Coordinator and Compliance Manager dated 1/31/25. This
document outlines the daily responsibilities for this position (PSA).
It is documented that daily this staff is required to do a walk-
through which involves watching cameras for 30-minutes,
observing youth and staff for 30 minutes and sending out an email
of the walk-through. It is also documented that this staff is to
check the Grievance Boxes twice a day and check the ORR
section 4 for any updated policies. Weekly, this staff is to check
with the HR department about new hires and check personal files
for several different items. Monthly, this staff is to check for
updated state policies, send emails to all staff who are on-call for
PSA, review new employee orientation, review the employee
handbook for acknowledgment of the focus of zero tolerance,
review youth files for PSA orientation.
Responsive Deployment Policy: PSA compliance Manager
job description not dated. The primary responsibility outlined in
this document is the prevention of sexual abuse in the program.
This position must ensure compliance will all governing bodies is
appropriate and must strictly enforce and adhere to the Zero
Tolerance Policy. This position is to investigate PSA grievances
and conduct quality assurance checks. This position is also to
conduct video monitoring for incident reports, staffing ratios
supervision of youth is being conducted as required.
HR file for Staff 2 was reviewed. Documentation indicates Staff
2 was hired on 7/22/24 and received her first disciplinary action on
7/25/24. Staff 2 received a written statement for a violation of the
dress code. Staff 2 received a second disciplinary action on
2/12/25 for a second violation of the dress code. It is documented
Staff 2 came to work “wearing high heels and a blouse that was
see-through”. A third disciplinary action was incurred on 4/18/25
which involved Staff 2 failing to follow instructions. It was found
that several required compliance forms were missing from
employee files which were the responsibility of Staff 2 to ensure
the forms were completed and in the files. Staff 2 was given until
4/22/2025 to ensure all required documentation is prepared and
ready for upload into the employee files. Leadership will meet with
Staff 2 to review the status of the files to confirm completion. The
fourth and final disciplinary action is documented as taking place
6

on 4/30/25 and resulted in termination from employment effective
4/30/25 for ongoing failure to perform essential job duties.
Youth A file which was closed at the time of his discharge
from the program on 1/31/25. Documentation indicates Youth A
entered the program on 12/29/24. There is no documentation of
any behavior incident involving a drawing of a naked female in the
file.
Youth B file which was closed at the time of his discharge
from the program on 1/18/25. Documentation indicates Youth B
entered the program on 12/30/24. There is no documentation of
any behavior incident involving a drawing of a naked female in the
file.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed at the facility. The facility is well
furnished and maintained. All of the grievances boxes were
examined as was the folder containing the grievances.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with evidence by interviews with
staff and documents reviews. There is no evidence to support the
allegation that management attempted to cover up the drawing by
an unknown youth. The action by the youth does not meet the
definition of abuse or harassment, thus there was reasons for this
issue to be reported and no violation of policy. This is evident by
the lack of a response by ORR when Staff 2 reported, reporting
the issue.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered in ensuring that a folder is kept
with each grievance along with placing the information in the
youth’s file.
Technical assistance was offered in the development of a
secondary level of review for compliance above the PSA position
to ensure the PSA staff is developing and completing appropriate
compliance steps.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
